content.description:
Start with low feet and both hands on the undercling.  Get low to traverse across to the bottom of the J (IMO most difficult part).  Work your hands and feet up the J.  Get a high foot on one of the little nubs.  When you can reach it, pull on a jug set back about a foot from the top right corner to top out.  

 Downclimb here or farther left on the south face.
content.protection: Crashpad, however the pebbles/sand don't do a terrible job at cushioning your fall
content.location: The climb all the way to the right on the south face.

content.description: Start low and work your way up the face.  There are lots of little nubs for feet on this slab climb. Play around with your foot angles, sometimes edge, sometimes smear.  Top out.
content.location: Left most climb of south face.

content.description:
Cube about 10 to 12 feet tall.  Rock is a dark shade of red/brown/black.     The sides of the boulder are aligned pretty well to a compass:   South side has the easiest climbing, there are lots of bumps to use as footholds.   West side is smooth and almost vertical, with a few small crimps to balance on your way up.   North side is overhung and it has the hardest problems.   East side -- TDB 

  The whole thing is in the intertidal zone, so climb at low tide.
